bioghist.p: The William J. Campbell Bookstore, founded in 1850 in Philadelphia by John Campbell, an English bookseller, also specialized in publishing local history and legal tracts. In 1874 William J. Campbell assumed direction over operations with the death of his father. In 1931 William's son John J. replaced his father and served at the helm until the store closed in 1951. The firm was instrumental in assembling the Franklin imprints collection at Yale and the Curtis Collection at University of Pennsylvania. John J. Campbell's son is William M. Campbell. William A.K. Martin (1817-1867) was a Philadelphia-born landscape, marine, and historical painter, whose work, Palermo, was shown at the Pennsylvania Academy in 1853. Henry A. Martin was a Philadelphia legal/naval print dealer. He was the uncle of John J. Campbell, and the Campbell firm was one of his principal clients.

scopecontent.p: The archives of the oldest family-operated bookstore in Philadelphia including personal and business correspondence, clippings, financial records, day books, legal documents, book catalogs, drawings, portrait engravings, maps, photographs, pamphlets, advertisements, sheet music, glass negatives, notebooks, postcards, newsletters, scrapbooks, brochures, and posters. The collection reflects the family's interest in Americana, local history, and legal literature. The collection contains the business papers of the founder, John Campbell; the personal letters of William M. Campbell; the business correspondence of William J. Campbell, 1895-1951, and his letterbooks, 1903-1925. As a noted publisher of Americana, Philadelphia/Pennsylvania history, and legal literature, the collection also contains manuscripts, photographs, brochures, and Campbell catalogs, 1866-1951. William J. Campbell was an officer of the City History Society of Philadelphia and the collection includes four boxes of materials such as organizational correspondence, newsletters, postcards, clippings, and scrapbooks, primarily for the 1920s. The collection also contains documents and photographs associated with Fairmount Park and Germantown. Correspondents also include Frances Campbell. The collection also contains two separate collections; the first, the correspondence of a Philadelphia legal/naval print dealer, Henry A. Martin; and the second, the correspondence of 19th century Philadelphia artist, William A.K. Martin and various members of his family, including his father, Captain John Martin, and his brother James F. Martin. The Henry A. Martin materials date from 1900 to 1927. The papers include a series of letters between Martin and the William J. Campbell Bookstore. Much of the correspondence is from Martin to John J. Campbell, and to William J. Campbell, from Chicago, Pittsburgh, Buffalo, Detroit, Cleveland, and Washington, D.C., as Martin traveled on collecting tours. Also included in the collection is family correspondence of William A.K. Martin. There are letters from Martin, as well as from the painter's father, Capt. John Martin; his brother, James F. Martin, a Philadelphia merchant dealing in wheat, oil, sugar, mackerel, and iron; the painter's son, Wm. A.K. Martin, Jr.; and a number of other relatives including Frances Martin and Eleanor Furlong. W.A.K. Martin's interests in European painting and his relationship with other artists in Nicaragua and Cuba are reflected in his letters. The letters of W.A.K. Martin, the artist, span the years 1833-1866.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
